controls.title: Ensure auditd is installed
controls.description: auditd is the userspace component to the Linux Auditing System. It's responsible for writing audit records to the disk.
controls.rationale: The capturing of system events provides system administrators with information to allow them to determine if unauthorized access to their system is occurring.
controls.audit:
Run the following command to verify auditd is installed:
# rpm -q audit audit-libs
audit-<version>
audit-libs-<version>
controls.remediation:
Run the following command to install auditd:
# dnf install audit audit-libs
controls.references: 1. See the auditd(8) and auditctl(8) man pages for more information.
controls.cis_controls:
v8: 8.2 Collect Audit Logs
v7: 6.2 Activate audit logging

controls.title: Ensure auditd service is enabled and running
controls.description: Turn on the auditd daemon to record system events.
controls.rationale: The capturing of system events provides system administrators with information to allow them to determine if unauthorized access to their system is occurring.
controls.audit:
Run the following command to verify auditd is enabled:
# systemctl is-enabled auditd
enabled
Run the following command to verify auditd is running:
# systemctl is-active auditd
active
controls.remediation:
Run the following command to enable auditd:
# systemctl --now enable auditd
controls.references: 1. See the auditd(8) man page for more information.
controls.cis_controls:
v8: 8.2 Collect Audit Logs
v7: 6.2 Activate audit logging

controls.title: Ensure auditing for processes that start prior to auditd is enabled
controls.description: Configure grub so that processes that are capable of being audited can be audited even if they start up prior to auditd startup.
controls.rationale: Audit events need to be captured on processes that start up prior to auditd, so that potential malicious activity cannot go undetected.
controls.audit:
Run the following command and verify that each linux line has the audit=1 parameter set:
# grubby --info=ALL | grep -Po 'audit=1'
audit=1
controls.remediation:
Edit /etc/default/grub and add audit=1 to GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX:
GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX="audit=1"
Run the following command to update the grub2 configuration:
# grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/grub2/grub.cfg
controls.references: 1. See the auditd(8) man page for more information.
controls.cis_controls:
v8: 8.2 Collect Audit Logs
v7: 6.2 Activate audit logging

controls.title: Ensure audit_backlog_limit is sufficient
controls.description: The backlog limit has a default setting of 64.
controls.rationale: During boot if audit=1, then the backlog will hold 64 records. If more than 64 records are created during boot, auditd records will be lost and potential malicious activity could go undetected.
controls.audit:
Run the following command and verify the audit_backlog_limit parameter is set to 8192 or larger:
# grubby --info=ALL | grep -Po 'audit_backlog_limit=\d+'
audit_backlog_limit=8192
controls.remediation:
Edit /etc/default/grub and add audit_backlog_limit=8192 to GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX:
GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX="audit_backlog_limit=8192"
Run the following command to update the grub2 configuration:
# grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/grub2/grub.cfg
controls.references: 1. See the auditd(8) man page for more information.
controls.cis_controls:
v8: 8.2 Collect Audit Logs
v7: 6.2 Activate audit logging
